- Constantly being pressured to "pitch in" (OT) as people are leaving by the masses and calls volume is increasing massively day by day. By the way, they dont reward you OT with more money btw. review_title: More than meets the eye, largely in a good way
pros: Working in Human Resources, I have a good view of what DBS seeks to do for employees. The awareness of diverse employee needs at different life stages and hence, policies becoming more flexible and equitable is encouraging to see. Grateful for a good culture nurtured by my team leader who cultivates psychological safety, and encourages our learning and growth. I also believe that DBS is going in the right direction bringing together staff with different expertise to collaborate and manage customer journeys from a holistic view instead of working in silos. The work is purposeful and the longer I've been here, the more I feel that DBS has good values, is sincere about social impact, and is building for a sustainable future.
cons:
As a large organisation, DBS inevitably has many processes and systems to navigate. To the bank's credit, there are many guides that have been written up to help staff navigate these and chatbots to assist, but sometimes it can still be hard to find an answer independently. Will need to count on colleagues 
to take time to help andd teach.

pros: Stable Job with good bonus ranging for 2-5months for junior employees (AVP and below) and up to 3.5months for senior employees (VP). Bonus highly dependent on your pay, higher your pay lower bonus in terms of months. Good for retirement when pay does not really matter
cons:
1. Not recommended for junior employees as junior employees (AVP & below) need to take on additional projects to promote while senior employees (VP) need not.
2. Very low increment (2% for non promotion years when salary is 6-7k and 4-7% for promotion) due to low benchmark set for ranks but is compensated for high bonus.
3. Any cash given out or off cycle adjustments will be taken into account in next year's bonus/increment. (i.e. No increment in 2021 due to less than ideal business performance, but was subsequently given a mid year adjustment due to business recovering. Mentioned was due to no increment during bonus earlier in the year. However, in 2022 bonus and increment cycle, mentioned that mid year adjustment was given resulting in lower/no increments.
4. Part of bonus paid out in shares which will be paid on the 3rd/4th/5th year from when the shares were issued. Part of the company's tactic as career hostage as these are given out to good performers, knowing that people junior employees might leave for better increments.
5. Management seem to emphasize on employee survey but takes ages to even try to improve. Most improvements are reactive measures.
6. Long hours
7. Generally more concern with senior employees than junior (VPs vs AVP and below)

review_title: Still a better coy than SMEs
pros:
Working in DBS is still very much better than being exploit in Singapore SMEs.
Depends on your role and attitude in job nature. It will significantly put you to be center of attention to provide solutions to business technologies and recognition from peers.
Probably one of the best employee benefits in general that enable to you to get lowest interest rate in home loan and higher rates in savings and also Shares allocation at 25% more base on your monthly contribution.
cons:
Too much redundant security measures such that developers are limited access to new technologies advancement and innovative. I cant use flutter and docker and k8s sadly to have my own playground. 
Most senior contributors and pioneers have left the role and can expect heavier responsibilities and efforts needed to maintain or scaling current BAU applications.

review_title: Great Company to Start Your Career
pros:
1. Lots of opportunities, job assignments, gets to improve quickly.
2. Buddy system helps to get new hire onboard and learn quickly.
3. Mentor system helps to guide new hire in career planning.
4. Colleagues and managers are helpful in resolving problems.
5. Lots of leave, leave approval system makes leave application quick and simple.
6. Lots of e-learning resources e.g. Linkedin Learning.
7. Regular catch-up with manager to discuss about career path and planning.
8. Various benefits and allowances
9. Able to work from home, flexible start and end time (when working in office), emphasis on work-life integration.
10. Accepting culture, managers able to accept new ideas and approaches.
11. Competitive salary.
12. Internal job opportunities and rotations available.
cons:
1. Lots of work load, OT is a norm, but you have to learn how to manage priorities and time.
2. Lots of meeting that take up most of the time during working hours, could only start working early in the morning or after working hours (OT).
3. Due to security reasons, access to tools is very restricted and limited.
4. When everyone is busy meeting it is difficult to get help, in the end have to resolve problems on your own.
5. Conflict of interest among colleagues can cause office politics.

Due to the internal transfer practice, it is a common sight that it produces weak middle management who aren't trained in the role that they transferred to, but their ego is too high to listen to feedback from "inexperience" fresh graduates and developers who "don't know anything" about the "business".

Many incompetent product owners and project managers resulted in endless and meaningless tech discussions that often go (something) like this...

Middle Management: "Can you draw a pair of lines that are parallel to each other? Oh! By the way, make them perpendicular too!"

Developers: "Ermmm... a pair of lines can't be parallel and perpendicular at the same time."

Middle Management: "Oh come on! You haven't even tried it!"

Developers: "Is just not possible... 🤦‍♂️ You know what? I'll give it a try and get back to you."

cons:
- no work life balance due to unrealistic expectations and deadlines, which bosses will couch as "pushing the boundaries", OT is a constant

- progression tend to be slow, gotta work yourself to the bone for recognition and promotion (and have to "market" your own achievements too)

- superficial attention to mental health (e.g. wellness talks, employee perks); the fundamental problem of being overworked is not addressed properly and there is little/no safety in discussing mental health issues with senior/middle mgmt

- HR leave employee welfare to managers to handle, dangerous especially if your manager is the toxic type. Be careful during resignation, make sure you know your rights cos HR will not help you.

review_title: Terrible Tech Leadership C2E and IBGT
pros: Great marketing on GANDALF, Transformation, Cloud and Being the best bank in the world
cons:
With over 20 years in Tech, I can safely say this is by far the worst Technology leadership I have seen in my career. Not just in India but in Singapore too.

C2E known to be the best culture is now ruined by the new leadership taking over in Singapore and Hyderabad. The 2 men put in these roles as head of C2E in Singapore and Hyderabad neither have leadership experience nor any knowledge of modern tech stack. These are dinosaurs been in the bank for decades and bringing the poor culture from their earlier LOBT to C2E. All the good work done by the predecessor is now seen as eroding. Many leaders have quit. 

In all DBS Open, T&O Open several feedback has been given and yet Piyush you have turned a blind eye. Running complex projects does not require a Hitler, it requires empathetic leadership. It requires younger people who bring in new ways of working and running things truly agile.

The new leader of C2E has zero interaction with the team. He operates in silos and in a manner that would have suited 25 years ago. No wonder so many people are leaving the bank.

Even in Hyderabad it is a sweatshop. Unrealistic timelines , agile for the sake of it, being pushed to work weekends. Some leaders are trying hard to change culture and bring in agile ways but it is not being heard. They are being shut down totally.

IBGT which is known to be the worst area of DBS is now slowly ruling C2E. It seems like they have put in a puppet in C2E who is so fearful of others that he simply cannot lead from the front. 

Piyush says that the company is agile, it is FAR from that.  Most leaders simply do not even know what agile roles are, what an agile team is and how it must operate. They just quote from some theory and expect that. Earlier leadership in C2E had brought in a great culture and brought in specialists to make this org Agile, but now the new leadership is wiping it all out in the name of cost saving. 

Piyush if you still do not open your eyes to reality and get down to the ground level, come to the next level leaders and talk to them then very soon this bank will go back to the stone age.

pros: Good training, young people with high energy
cons: Only join if you already have money. You are expected to pay for your own papers that can amount to up to $1,000 or more, and they will only reimburse you if you pass, and even that would be after many months. Additionally, Human Resources are very vague, and will fire you even if you are trying to clarify issues that they did not ask in the first place under the guise of withholding of information. Only join if you are prepared to leave with a bad offboarding letter.

pros: Work life balance and you are in control of your own business. Good employee benefits.
cons:
Overpromised bonus payout. During the whole of last year, management keep on going with the “the bank will never shortchange you”. 

Basically sold you a dream but when it comes to the actual payout, it’s a horror. 

Promotion based on bell curve. Unclear direction of the whole business model. 

Well, if you are looking for a sales job that doesn’t pay you according to your effort or any benchmark, with unclear promotion criteria then this is the place for you.

pros: Flexibility, innovative, learning curves, growth, different from other local banks

pros:
Pros

- Good Development team
- Relatively good extra benefits
cons:
1. Poor upper management planning when it comes to tech projects. Basically, whatever they want, they just open their mouth and expect you to finish it with a random deadline based on how they feel.
- They will over-commit to a deadline without listening to the development team's advice and without any consideration of the current workload and manpower available for the task.

- Goals, product features, and objectives shifts. Eg. in sprint 1, the goal was to get Model A working. But at the end of sprint 1, Management suddenly expects Model A, B, and C to work.
- Upper management expects developers to make up for their poor planning and management skills in the form of working on Sundays and Saturdays till 2 am.

Result: Engineers are overworked, underappreciated and management only provides lip service with no compensation. (And yes, we have worked Sat and Sundays for 3 weeks in a row).


2. Poor pay, Politics, and lies. Pay is not adjusted to the market rate. Despite getting external concrete offers, management lied about trying to increase the pay rate to match. Management only provides lip service without even actually speaking with HR etc. They provide excuses like not having enough budget, then immediately hire 2 -3 more junior engineers whom I have to train and are less qualified but with a better salaray?!
Upper management only rewards those who talk and demand a lot, not those who actually do the work.

Results: creates a lot of distrust between employees and management. Causes a lot of fiction and distrust between colleagues as everyone is fighting to be heard. Also encourages solo work to be done than collaborative work.

3. Upper management hires managers that are unskilled in terms of soft skills and hard skills. This causes a lot of issues between upper management, middle management, and developers.

- Middle management would present things and deadlines to upper management with no regard for developers. Everyone is just focused on what they want.

staff benefits
bonus given

Unfair wages and evaluation
those that are good at boot licking get high increment and bonus when they do much less then average people.

pros:
-Pushing employees to be more data driven
-Promote learning as DBS will offer you a lot of free courses
- Very professional working environment, because you will just talk about work all the time.
cons:
1. Assign heavy workload and expect things to be delivered within a short of time. Not because you have problem with time management, it is mainly because of understaff, meeting schedule too packed, more work piling up everyday, and work delay due to data source issues.
2. Long working hour because of workload too much and need to spend extra hours to do all the unnecessary trouble shooting thanks to the poor data migration process.
3. No work life balance. Not only you, your boss and your colleagues are all insanely hardworking. It's normal to work until 3-4am during Weekday. You thought you can take a break during Weekends, Annual Leave and Sick Leave? No way! You are entitled with 24days annual leave, but believe me, you will never use it for leisure purposes.
4. Nobody will care about your mental health and physical health. All they care is 'donation' and support 'volunteering' work outside of the company. So that branding can be promoted. 
5. High expectation from management and bosses, your works will never be appreciated.
6. Employee Turn-Over Rate is increasing. More and more people are leaving the company, at least 2-3 people you know will be leaving every month.
7. Meeting cultures are bad and some meetings are useless. You will spend one whole day to attend meeting, because most of the meetings last for at least 1hour,and some meetings are only 10% relevant to you or for your update/knowledge sharing only.
8. No time to do all those free courses, no time to do team bonding, no time to do small talk with your colleagues.
9. Bad planning and a lot of old problems need to clear. Some items have been pending for years or months, but nobody do it until you take the ownership.
10. People are not very helpful because they are too busy with their own work and clearing backlog. When you need help, the only way is to ping the person multiple times or escalate through emails cc his/her boss.

pros: Organised, well-resourced, benefits, regular hours, pro family.

review_title: success is largely dependent on your port. lots of servicing to do in addition to hitting KPI
pros: largest customer base among premier banking platforms in singapore. people are generally nice, colleagues will help you if you ask for assistance but similarly, if you don't voice out, nobody will help cos people will just do their own work. every RM is given an ipad for appointments and to close cases, app is generally smooth and easy to navigate though there will be hiccups at times. financing rates (for wealth products) are pretty competitive, normally management will agree to match competitors' rates but alot of times, the rates provided are already better than competitors.
cons: your success as a RM really depends on your port. if your port is bad, chances are you are very likely not going to do well even if your manager says otherwise as it's just not sustainable in the long run. things like AUM, deposits etc do not count towards your KPI. there are also lots of servicing to do which will take up a large portion of your time, in addition to running sales. this will be worse if your port is bad. the training provided is practically useless, you learn almost nothing and the systems used; process and flow etc are not taught at all. lots of on-the-job learning and very steep learning curve if you are new to premier banking. if you don't voice out and don't seek for assistance at the start, you will still be struggling after months as some systems are not easy to use at all. it can be a very sales-oriented culture depending on the centres you are posted to - some managers will push you to sell certain products, even if your clients might not need it as they need to hit the KPI for the products and to look good in front of their bosses. if you fall short, you will be reprimanded in various ways. not all managers are competent; some are nice as individuals but do not know how to groom or help their staff (especially newbies). MBFC is known to be the centre with the worst port so if you are posted to MBFC, then good luck to you. turnover rate at MBFC is perhaps the highest among all the centres due to this reason. compensation is also not attractive as compared to other banks with similar roles.

review_title: Too many clients + workload and not enough employees
pros:
Staff preferential loan interest rate
Helpful colleagues despite the workload
cons:
The customer base is too large and there are not enough staff support across all departments, be it IT, compliance, front office and credit. For example, the credit department has to support all 3 segments of Treasures, TPC and Private Banking (that is a LARGE number of clients), and that team has less than 15 people.

The compliance department is seriously understaffed too, with many of them working till late at night. I'm pretty sure MAS Notice 626 states to allocate sufficient resources to monitoring/compliance functions based on the size of the bank, and I am not seeing that happening.

Various departments take forever to revert, not because they are incompetent; there is simply too much workload for everyone.

review_title: Fantastic perks, lots of resources, very hierarchical.
pros:
Employee benefits is unparalleled. It's an extremely fun and volatile place to work at as everyone is young and hungry to prove themselves. There are a lot of awards and recognitions to achieve and if you work hard, and if you do, you will get compensated handsomely.

If you navigate your way smartly, you will find huge growth on the personal and professional level.
cons:
- There's a lot of bootlicking up the ladder.
- Word spreads like wildfire within the distribution
- As with anywhere else, there is politicking.
- Do you have a hobby? A favourite pastime? Be prepared to reminisce about it a lot because it's going to be a thing of the past.
